dl.dd: This free online encyclopedia of philosophy is a valuable resource.
The programming languages weblog, hosts loads of interesting discussions and links.
Collection of programming language theory texts and resources, all of which are freely available over the Internet, maintained by Frank Atanassow.
Free (refereed) online journal on the “theoretical and practical areas in computer science involving logical methods, taken in a broad sense.”
This is a work in progress by Peter Smith that will become a book discussing Gödel's incompleteness theorems and the philosophical implications. It's accessible for undergraduates (like me).
An extensive resource on the use of LaTeX for typesetting documents aimed at logicians, but equally usefull for mathematicians and others.
The classic American English writing style guide by William Strunk, Jr.
Another well-known style guide for American English writing, focussing more on presentational style and less on usage.
dl.dt: Finally, one inline advice (taken from the excellent hawiki QuotesPage):

dd.pre: <shapr> how will you know when you've written enough? <kosmikus> I don't really know yet, but one of the following: (a) if my supervisor tells me I have, (b) if every chapter heading has content following it, (c) if the deadline is there <shapr> that's an excellent heuristic
